title: Will Ketanji Brown Jackson be confirmed by the Senate before 1 May 2022?
preds: There seems to be no split among the Democrats, and a few Republicans have gotten on board. It's clear that the Republicans have not found anything to hold against her, and have resorted to mere showboating. Things will not change, and she will be confirmed.
Mitt Romeny and GOP votes make this more likely.
with anticipation of vote today and 3 Republicans stating they will vote for her
As of Apr 5 - she has 53 in favor vs 47 https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/interactive/2022/ketanji-brown-jackson-confirmation-vote/
Support from 3 republican senators and Democrats ensure confirmation.
Given support from swing democrats and at least one republican, this seems very likely
Good luck and hopes for smooth sailing here
The Republicans' grownup caucus has spoken.  She's in.
The recent slow drip of support from a few Republican senators for KBJ is indicative that her confirmation should pass.
Looking almost certain that this will be further supported and passed.

Now the big hurdle has passed it is much clearer -but I still expect the GOP to filibuster for the  hours - There are still many ways to delay. GOP can still push it or try to after Easter holiday, saying Dems are shoving it through, wait until afterwards. GOP will not want to go home to constituents if she is confirmed. GOP would rather wait until after recess.
Murkowski and Romney on board.  Only a Republican filibuster to block at this point it seems.
With Collins stating that she's a yes vote, it's all but over.
A full vote is expected in April, with all Democrats and at least one Republican in her favour.
Sounds like this is scheduled and going to happen shortly
Overall, consensus seems to be that this will happen.
The first Republican has hopped on the band wagon.
Collins is acting iffy no longer; all-in.
Manchin on board, Romney on board.  Its a lock if no one strays regardless of Sinema.  If Collins or Murkowski join its done.

Repeating my forecast. 
AP: "The Senate Judiciary Committee has set a vote next week to recommend nominee Ketanji Brown Jackson to the full Senate. Jackson's confirmation as the first Black woman on the Supreme Court appears likely by mid-April."

https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2022/03/28/ketanji-brown-jackson-meeting-senators-nomination-judiciary/ timeline seems set for vote next week -- doesnt seem like there's a major issue here -- 1% chance of someone missing the vote or a big vote buster but seems unlikely here. Hearings seemed relatively civil.
Manchin on board and no visible road blocks.
Seems like Manchin is going to go along with her.  As long as Democrats stay together, she should be okay

Mostly following the crowd, but bumping down as I suspect many are not fully considering the deadline. From quick wikipedia scan, it seems like this question's deadline allows for the process to be slightly longer than the recent average length of ~54 days. I would guess this one is substantially faster than average given the president's party controls the Senate. Plus we are now well into the hearings with no indications of Democrats breaking with the party. But, the deadline question still injects more uncertainty into this forecast than I think the crowd is accounting for. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nomination_and_confirmation_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States
With Manchin in, it should happen soon.

Aiming for the judiciary committee vote on April 4th (https://www.cnbc.com/2022/03/24/supreme-court-pick-ketanji-brown-jackson-confirmation-what-happens-next.html), Manchin said he'll vote for her (https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/25/politics/joe-manchin-ketanji-brown-jackson-vote/index.html), and nothing substantive came up in the hearings, which eliminates most of the chances for the confirmation to be shot down. Average time from judiciary committee vote to Senate confirmation is 8 days, longest being 16 for Kagan, so this looks like a pretty sure bet at this point.
Republican Senators Say No Boycott Planned for Jackson Committee Vote https://www.wsj.com/articles/republican-senators-say-no-boycott-planned-for-jackson-committee-vote-11648148340
Another favorable day of confirmation hearings
The hearings are progressing and there is still no sign the democrats will not meet their early April confirmation timeline.

Likely a bi-partisan vote, but with Democrats holding 50 and all she needs is 51, it is fairly likely she will. The question is when.
McConnell says Nay, could mean backroom ways to delay or worse, kick it off completely. That would be too risky given it would demonstrate that the GOP focuses on tweets and having evidence they are derailing a nomination again. (aka. Garland). RBG was 50 days and Barret was slammed in at 30 days. 
The average is around 70 days for confirmation.
 If there are no more circus tricks like boycotting the committee, it should be smooth. If games are played, then this will play out longer. April recess will happen, and then the question is how long it takes to bring it to a vote. The Process     The President usually will consult with Senators before announcing a nomination.     When the President nominates a candidate, the nomination is sent to the Senate Judiciary Committee for consideration.     The Senate Judiciary Committee holds a hearing on the nominee. The Committee usually takes a month to collect and receive all necessary records, from the FBI and other sources, about the nominee and for the nominee to be prepared for the hearings.     During the hearings, witnesses, both supporting and opposing the nomination, present their views. Senators question the nominee on his or her qualifications, judgment, and philosophy.     The Judiciary Committee then votes on the nomination and sends its recommendation (that it be confirmed, that it be rejected, or with no recommendation) to the full Senate.     The full Senate debates the nomination.     The Senate rules used to allow unlimited debate (a practice known as filibustering) and to end the debate, it required the votes of 3/5 of the Senate or 60 senators (known as the cloture vote).  In April 2017, the Senate changed this rule and lowered the required votes to 51 to end debate on Supreme Court nominations (this is commonly known as "the nuclear option").     When the debate ends, the Senate votes on the nomination. A simple majority of the Senators present and voting is required for the judicial nominee to be confirmed. If there is a tie, the Vice President who also presides over the Senate casts the deciding vote.
Yes, with hearings currently underway, I cannot imagine such a intelligent and qualified candidate will be denied an open seat on the bench within the month of April.
Strong probability that this will happen.

Judge Brown is highly qualified, while there are some senators who might wish to delay a vote but that simply isn't possible since in 2017, Senate Republicans under Majority Leader Mitch McConnell changes the rules to end the filibuster for Supreme Court nominees, which then allowed Neil Gorsuch to be confirmed. On top of this Judge Brown is likely to pick up at least a couple of Republican votes as well.
Another non controversial day at the hearings.
It's looking good but there are potential curve balls including the apparent frailty of Clarence Thomas
+20 to follow the crowd, it sounds like the hearings are going well and things seem like they'll proceed fairly quickly.

Seems to be handling herself well, presenting a pleasant contrast to the buffoonery of the Honourable Ted Cruz and the Honourable Josh Hawley.  .  And when I say "Honourable" I mean "shameless." Doesn't matter, though, as long as all the Ds stay on side.  She might even pick up some R votes on the floor; there appears to be some integrity nibbling around the edges of my party's caucus.  Should happen fairly fast once the JudComm is done.   The Honourable (supra) Minority Leader Yertle the Turtle will doubtless pull some procedural shenanigans to delay it, but he'll be just be doing that to keep in practice.  If Mr. Justice Thomas hits the skids, though, all bets are off.  She'll still get confirmed in that case, but it will take longer and be nastier.

There are no skeletons in her closet. There are enough votes to have her confirmed. She has been scrutinized and vetted through other appointments and she is the first black female will serve on the Supreme Court. Any opposition to her appointment is not in any way substantial and a flimsy attempt at political posturing.

This should remind the Ds that they need to get this week's nominee through fast--if somebody on the Thomas-Trump-Turtle team kicks the bucket, the Rs will fight very hard to keep The Current Incumbent from filling the seat, so the Breyer patch needs to be dealt with quickly, just in case.

Republicans are critical of her record on some issues (e.g. saying she's too lenient in sentencing) but are still heaping praise on her credentials and intelligence. Reminiscent of Justice Barrett. So I don't see this failing

As many other forecasters have mentioned, while the average time between nomination and confirmation has be 68 days, the average time between nomination and first hearing has been 41 days (i.e. more than half the time). https://www.cbsnews.com/live-updates/ketanji-brown-jacksons-confirmation-hearings-live-stream/

The GOP has nothing to gain by stalling until after the midterms. Holding the seat open for nearly three years is unrealistic, so why drag this out? As nominations rarely get struck down, the odds are high unless procedural issues delay the timing beyond May 1.
Not seeing any major pushback from conservative media on this and the low stakes for the GOP at this stage considering the Supreme Court make up.  The main risk is procedural

This would be at the low end of the range for recent confirmations not counting Coney Barrett.   Reluctance to make this a mid term election issue by republicans so unless they stall,  within the range of normal process.

Hearings will begin 21MAR and Democratic leaders are setting a goal to confirm her by 08APR. With generally bipartisan support from what I understand (at least enough to be nominated) I don’t see this dragging out. (https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/02/politics/ketanji-brown-jackson-capitol-hill-meetings/index.html). By my count 26 of the last 67 (39%) Supreme Court Justices took longer than the 39 days which would end for Jackson on 08APR.

Seeing Republican opposition rhetoric ramp up and I think there is a real but low probability the nomination gets blocked (or drawn out) on the basis of her views on race, crime, etc..
My outside view is the confirmation rate since 1945 (73%), adjusted to the current sentiment.

"Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell told @hughhewitt Ketanji Brown Jackson will be "treated respectfully" during her confirmation hearing and added he thinks she is "highly likely" to be confirmed to the Supreme Court."
https://twitter.com/DaniellaMicaela/status/1504444695736463362 So McConnell will complain, but there won't be a giant attempt to block her confirmation. It's simply too early in Biden's presidency for that to work.

41 days remaining and 13 days elapsed, so she would have to be confirmed in less than 54 days. Taking the outside view the base rate since 1975 is 68 days [2]. The last justice prior to Barrett to be confirmed in less than 54 days was Roberts in 2005 (so of those eventually confirmed that's 2 out of 7 or 29%) [1]. However, according to [3] the average time to first hearing was 41 days, and Jackson is scheduled to start March 21 [4]. That's only 24 days. So that makes average time from hearing starting to confirmation about 27 days, and means she would on average be confirmed by about April 20. Taking the inside view it appears she has little resistance and I'd give a 95% chance she's eventually confirmed. So overall I think confirmation is decently likely by May 1, though the window is kind of tight. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nominations_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States [2] https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2022/01/26/supreme-court-nominations/9228216002/ [3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nomination_and_confirmation_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States#:~:text=Since%201974%2C%20the%20average%20time,for%20four%20or%20five%20days. [4] https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2022-03-02/supreme-court-hearings-will-start-march-21-democrats-aim-for-jackson-confirmation-before-easter

Initial Forecast 3/17:  Confirmation hearings begin 3/21.  Average confirmation time since 1975 has been 68 days which would exceed the end of the question.  Last confirmation was Barrett who was quickly confirmed in 35 days which was fastest ever due to the impending election where Republicans were expecting to lose their majority.  Don't expect a repeat.  Jackson's confirmation requires all 50 democratic senators to approve and given the average length of time, this is improbable by May 1st.

If Jackson is confirmed I believe it will be relatively quickly given the precedent set by the last confirmation of a Supreme Court judge and that the confirmation will essentially come down to 2 senators. I think the question is mainly a matter of whether all democratic senators support Jackson or not.

Of the three GOP senators who voted for her confirmation to the DC circuit court (Graham, Murkowski, and Collins), only Collins is acting iffy (and i think that's just political theater). Even two GOP senators would almost assure her confirmation. (my first prediction was fueled by feelings, not by thinkings)

I was quick to vote this morning without doing my inside view due diligence -- it appears the push is being made to get the confirmation done before the April 8 departure / two week break. And they seem on pace. With no notable abscenes on the Democrats side it appears they have the votes to get it done efficiently. I do leave some margin of error for a Democrat flip / an issue to delay the process.

She is still going through vetting.  Anything could still surface to show she is not a viable candidate.  But also the Democrats have to persuade all 50 members to vote for her.  Something they’ve been struggling with.  Also 1 May is only 6 weeks away now so time is starting to run out for the question. More likely to happen than not, but by 1st May, not sure.

Outside view:
61 days between nomination and required approval date
About 50% of past nominations have made it in that deadline
About 25% of past nominations have failed to make it at all We can't use conditional probability too easily here because many of them will have failed after the 61 days, but it probably leads to an outside view that this has around 30-50% chance of happening. Inside view:
As @slapthepancake points out, the hearings are starting very soon, and the likelihood is that if the confirmation is approved, then it will make it within that time frame. I'm assuming also that within that 25%, some fail before the first hearing.

I give this event a relatively high likelihood. The time it usually takes for a confirmation to go through is covered by the given window. Problems within the democratic party over this candidate look unlikely given the upcoming midterm elections, the stakes might be too high for dissent, even with Manchin. Republicans might not see it as worthwile to make take their issues with the process or the candidate herself to the centre stage, since there are more easily digestable narratives to attack their political opponents with. In this time during Joe Biden's presidency it is also unlikely that calls for a delay to a next term would emerge.

Outside rate for this for me is near-100%. Hearings start March 21, and there's 41 days between then and the question close. The time from start of judiciary committee hearings to confirmation by the Senate for the past 7 justices have all been <41 days. The longest was Kagan at 38. From a scheduling perspective 41 days is plenty of time, and Dick Durbin who chairs the Judiciary Committee has said there's "no reason to wait or delay" (https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/democrats-set-judge-jacksons-confirmation-hearings-march-21/story?id=83207791). The average time from nomination to start of hearings since Roberts is 41 days, and Jackson's wait was only 21, so he seems to be making good on that promise. Barring Durbin scheduling the Judiciary Committee vote super late for some reason, there shouldn't be an issue with timing.  In terms of votes, there don't seem to be any major causes for concern. There's been no vocal opposition to her confirmation, no scandals thus far, and Democrats have enough votes on paper to get her through. There's no apparent motive at this point for Republicans to put up a huge fight either, the court will stay 6-3 conservative and rejecting her still leaves enough time for Democrats to simply nominate another justice and confirm them before the midterms (https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2022/03/14/whats-ahead-for-ketanji-brown-jackson-heres-what-recent-history-suggests/). Republicans strategy so far appears to be to play nice and act respectful to try to contrast with how contentious the past few nominations have been with Democrats.  For secondary concerns, Joe Manchin may be a problem, but I would imagine that Joe Biden would talk to him about how he intended to vote before nominating her, so I don't anticipate any problems. He voted for her for the circuit court (https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_votes/vote1171/vote_117_1_00231.htm), so he's a near-certain yes, barring something happening in the hearings. Unconfirmed nominees have been pretty rare, with only 3 from 1987 to now. Merrick Garland was one but that was unrelated to his qualifications, one was Harriet Miers who was retracted because of immediate same-party opposition, and one was Robert Bork, who was hugely controversial immediately as well. Only Bork was arguably not confirmed because of hearings.  The main thing to watch will be the hearings. The hearings may be ugly because its a modern SCOTUS confirmation hearing, or it may be less contentious if Republicans' strategy as they've mentioned is to be nicer now that the appointment is less consequential. Regardless, hearings derailing the nomination would historically be an anomaly. Its unlikely to be Kavanaugh-esque if the best scandal we've heard so far is wondering what her LSAT score is. I'm reserving only 7% for the off-chance of some random scandal, or her performing very poorly due to a possible lack of prep time due to the short schedule.  Days from start of hearings to confirmation:
Barrett - 14
Kavanaugh - 32
Gorsuch - 18
Kagan - 38
Sotomayor - 24
Alito - 22
Roberts - 17

Believe the average time it takes to confirm a justice from nomination is 67-70 days (Average / median). So that pushes past Feb 25. Given partisanship has eroded over the last few years, I'd lean towards a longer-than-usual nomination. Some good datapoints here: https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2022/03/14/whats-ahead-for-ketanji-brown-jackson-heres-what-recent-history-suggests/ -- overall, seems slim this gets done by May 1
Females seem to all have relatively short timelines for confirmation, coupled with Brown’s previous confirmation success the odds seem very likely.

I counted 2 / 11 cases (18%) in the modern era that were confirmed so quickly after nomination.  But the Senate appears to have a schedule to beat that timeline with hearings starting 21 March.  So I guess I will give the schedule the benefit of the doubt and adjust sharply lower if delays appear.
There's no indication that any Democrat Senator will oppose her, and that's all that's needed for her confirmation, together if necessary with the Vice President's casting vote.

On the one hand, she doesn't mutiple credible allegations of sexual assault against her, but on the other hand she's a she, a non-white one at that and, worst of all, Senator McConnell is still in office. Nominees in the 21st century have averaged at just under 70 days until confirmation. It might happen.

It is 62 days from when Ketanji Brown Jackson when was first nominated on the 28/2/22 to the 30/4/22. Looking at the most recent 15 US Supreme Court Nominations (But Excluding Merrick Garland in 2016 and Roberts First Nomination in 2005) -
https://www.senate.gov/legislative/nominations/SupremeCourtNominations1789present.htm I found that -
Jackson Is Confirmed By The Senate Before 1/5/22 = 27% = 4/15 = Nomination Process Is Within 62 Days
Jackson Isn't Confirmed By The Senate Before 1/5/22 = 73% = 11/15 = Nomination Process Exceeds 62 Days / Nominee is Rejected
Fully expect hearings to be utilized as a showcase for expressing opposition to the values and goals of the Biden Administration.
Up 20% since the consensus is so high. Useful link by @zbucklyo below.

About 40 days from the expected start of the proceedings.  Good piece by the Brookings Institute on how the confirmation process has taken longer as partisanship has increased - even Barrett's nomination took over 20 days, and that was rushed through as quickly as possible.  Since the rush isn't needed here, and there are other big doings (e.g., Ukraine) this seems less than likely. https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2022/03/14/whats-ahead-for-ketanji-brown-jackson-heres-what-recent-history-suggests/

In the survey phase, I put something like 46% (Oh, how I wish I had saved ALL my forecasts to reduce noise!). It was clear to me that May 1 was just below the average length for even similar instances. But it seems I have missed certain things and things seem different here. My uncertainty remaining is for the historical instances of rejection, since I have almost ruled out withdrawals or lapses due to Congressional recess. UPDATE: I have found all my estimates from phase 1. I will see if I should use it to average out my current guesses.

Going up based on the fact that the hearings are supposed to start next Monday as @AnotherWorld pointed out. It seems like Amy Coney Barrett, rather than a deviation from the norm. may have set a new precedent for what is considered quick.
Wow I did not take into consideration the time frame on the question I have to say no unless it happens between the 22-24 march

I think with so many larger issues going on (ie Covid, Russia-Ukraine, Inflation, etc.) I don't think it makes a whole lot of sense for this confirmation to become a big battle. Especially since this will be a Liberal Judge replacing a Liberal judge on a Conservative leaning court. It seems like there is not much to be gained from fighting the nominee unless a) there is something uniquely disqualifying about her we do not already know. (Unlikely as imagine she has been carefully vetted by the Biden team) or b) Republicans believe there are points to be gained with voters by fighting the confirmation. I am leaving a 20% margin of error to cover those cases, but ultimately I haven't really seen this topic break out of political circles and into the general public discourse. And with Major world events that I think are more top of mind right now, I don't see it doing so any time soon. As such there is nothing really to be gained from opposing the confirmation.

So it looks like the confirmation hearing is scheduled to be relatively soon: https://edition.cnn.com/2022/03/02/politics/ketanji-brown-jackson-capitol-hill-meetings/index.html "Confirmation hearings for the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson will begin on March 21, the Senate Judiciary Committee announced Wednesday, with Democratic leaders setting a goal of reaching a final Senate vote by April 8." There could be some unexpected delay, but I think that is a low probability, the bigger concern is if Manchin decides to block this. https://www.politico.com/video/2022/03/10/manchin-says-he-didnt-see-any-red-flags-after-meeting-with-ketanji-brown-jackson-510121 I don't put a lot of stock in anything Manchin says at this point, but he hasn't thrown cold water on the party *yet*.

Looking at the time it took for a nominated Justice to be confirmed by the Senate, having Ketanji Brown Jackson confirmed by the Senate before 1 May 2022 would be a quicker than average confirmation. I believe the democrats stated that they wanted at least some form of bipartisan support, and Republicans are likely to be annoying, which does not bode well for this question's timeline.
Hearings start on March 21 and unless there is some unexpected skeleton uncovered this should be pretty easy sailing, similar to Barrett

Initial forecast to be above the consensus. A comparison class might be the work the US Congress is getting done on some non-marquee 46 issues. I expect absent some bombshells (not a good word right now), that enough GOP Senators will tack to the normal "good idea to have both qualified and balanced" SCOTUS justices. YMMV

"The Hill" source not that impressive considering they spelt Ketanji Brown Jackson's name wrong on the first line of the article.  History and the current political environment suggests low appetite for delay tactics on this confirmation https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2022/03/14/whats-ahead-for-ketanji-brown-jackson-heres-what-recent-history-suggests/
